_link.title: I can identify the names of key groups in the periodic table

toLevel2.question: What is the name of the group of elements found in Group 1 of the periodic table?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Group 1 elements (excluding hydrogen) are called the alkali metals.

distractors.explanation: Noble gases are in Group 18, not Group 1.
Halogens are in Group 17, not Group 1.
Alkaline earth metals are in Group 2, not Group 1.

toLevel2.question: Which group in the periodic table contains the halogens?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: The halogens (fluorine, chlorine, bromine, iodine, astatine) are found in Group 17.

distractors.explanation: Group 1 contains the alkali metals, not the halogens.
Group 18 contains the noble gases, not the halogens.
Group 2 contains the alkaline earth metals, not the halogens.

toLevel2.question: What is the name of the elements in Group 18 of the periodic table?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Group 18 elements are called the noble gases because they are very stable and unreactive.

distractors.explanation: Halogens are in Group 17, not Group 18.
Alkali metals are in Group 1, not Group 18.
Transition metals are in the central block, not Group 18.

toLevel2.question: Which of the following elements is a halogen?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Chlorine is in Group 17 and is one of the halogen elements.

distractors.explanation: Sodium is in Group 1 and is an alkali metal.
Neon is in Group 18 and is a noble gas.
Calcium is in Group 2 and is an alkaline earth metal.

toLevel2.question: What is the name of the group of elements in Group 2 of the periodic table?
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Group 2 elements are called the alkaline earth metals.

distractors.explanation: Alkali metals are in Group 1, not Group 2.
Halogens are in Group 17, not Group 2.
Noble gases are in Group 18, not Group 2.

toLevel2.question: The noble gases are found in Group 1 of the periodic table.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: Noble gases are found in Group 18, the last group on the right side of the periodic table.

distractors.explanation: Students may confuse group positions; Group 1 contains the alkali metals, not the noble gases.

toLevel2.question: Fluorine, chlorine, and bromine are all halogens.
toLevel2.correctExplanation: All three are in Group 17, which is the halogen group.

distractors.explanation: Students may not recognise all three as halogens, but they are all in Group 17.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the sentence about key group names.
toLevel2.sentence: The elements in Group 1 are called the {{blank:1}} and the elements in Group 17 are called the {{blank:2}}.

1.correctExplanation: Group 1 elements are known as the alkali metals.

distractors.explanation: Noble gases are in Group 18, not Group 1.
Halogens are in Group 17, not Group 1.

2.correctExplanation: Group 17 elements are known as the halogens.

distractors.explanation: Noble gases are in Group 18, not Group 17.
Alkali metals are in Group 1, not Group 17.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the sentence about noble gases.
toLevel2.sentence: The {{blank:1}} are found in Group {{blank:2}} of the periodic table and include elements such as helium, neon, and argon.

1.correctExplanation: Helium, neon, and argon are all noble gases.

distractors.explanation: Halogens include fluorine, chlorine, and bromine, not helium and neon.
Alkali metals include lithium, sodium, and potassium, not helium and neon.

2.correctExplanation: Noble gases occupy Group 18, the rightmost group of the periodic table.

distractors.explanation: Group 1 contains the alkali metals, not the noble gases.
Group 17 contains the halogens, not the noble gases.

toLevel2.prompt: Complete the sentence about alkaline earth metals.
toLevel2.sentence: Group 2 of the periodic table contains the {{blank:1}}, which includes elements such as magnesium and {{blank:2}}.

1.correctExplanation: Group 2 elements are called the alkaline earth metals.

distractors.explanation: Alkali metals are in Group 1; Group 2 has the alkaline earth metals.
Transition metals are in the central block of the periodic table, not Group 2.

2.correctExplanation: Calcium is an alkaline earth metal in Group 2.

distractors.explanation: Sodium is in Group 1 (alkali metals), not Group 2.
Chlorine is in Group 17 (halogens), not Group 2.

toLevel3.question: Why are Group 18 elements called 'noble' gases?
toLevel3.correct: They are very stable and rarely react with other elements
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The term 'noble' reflects their lack of reactivity, similar to how noble metals resist corrosion.

distractors.answer: They are the most expensive and rare gases on Earth
distractors.explanation: Some noble gases like argon are quite common; the name refers to their unreactivity, not rarity.

distractors.answer: They were discovered by scientists of noble birth or high status
distractors.explanation: The name relates to chemical behaviour, not the discoverers' social standing.

distractors.answer: They only exist in their pure form and cannot form any compounds at all
distractors.explanation: Noble gases can form compounds under extreme conditions; they are simply very reluctant to react.

toLevel3.question: What do all alkali metals in Group 1 have in common in terms of electron arrangement?
toLevel3.correct: They all have 1 electron in their outer shell
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Group 1 elements share 1 valence electron, which gives them similar chemical properties.

distractors.answer: They all have the same total number of electrons
distractors.explanation: Total electron count varies; lithium has 3, sodium has 11, etc.

distractors.answer: They all have 1 electron shell containing electrons
distractors.explanation: Only hydrogen has 1 shell; sodium has 3, potassium has 4, etc.

distractors.answer: They all have a full outer shell of electrons already
distractors.explanation: A full outer shell describes noble gases; alkali metals have just 1 valence electron.

toLevel3.question: Why do all halogens have similar chemical properties?
toLevel3.correct: They all have 7 electrons in their outer shell
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Chemical properties are determined by valence electrons. All halogens have 7, making them behave similarly.

distractors.answer: They all have the same number of electron shells
distractors.explanation: Fluorine has 2 shells, chlorine has 3, bromine has 4; they differ in shell count.

distractors.answer: They are all found in the same period of the periodic table
distractors.explanation: Halogens span multiple periods; they share a group, not a period.

distractors.answer: They all have the same atomic mass and similar densities
distractors.explanation: Halogen masses vary greatly (F=19, Cl=35.5, Br=80, I=127).

toLevel3.question: How does the position of a group on the periodic table relate to the properties of its elements?
toLevel3.correct: Elements in the same group have the same number of valence electrons and similar chemical properties
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Groups share the same valence electron count, which is the primary determinant of chemical behaviour.

distractors.answer: Elements in the same group have the same number of shells and similar physical properties
distractors.explanation: Same shells means same period, not same group.

distractors.answer: Elements in the same group have the same total number of electrons in their atoms
distractors.explanation: Total electrons vary down a group; it is valence electrons that remain the same.

distractors.answer: Elements in the same group have identical physical and chemical properties overall
distractors.explanation: Chemical properties are similar but not identical; physical properties differ significantly down a group.

toLevel3.question: Why is hydrogen sometimes placed separately from Group 1 even though it has 1 valence electron?
toLevel3.correct: Hydrogen is a non-metal and behaves very differently from the alkali metals
toLevel3.correctExplanation: Despite having 1 valence electron, hydrogen is a gas and a non-metal, unlike the reactive metallic elements in Group 1.

distractors.answer: Hydrogen has no protons, making it fundamentally different from all other elements
distractors.explanation: Hydrogen has 1 proton; it is not missing protons.

distractors.answer: Hydrogen belongs in Group 17 because it can gain electrons like a halogen
distractors.explanation: While hydrogen can gain an electron, it is not classified as a halogen.

distractors.answer: Hydrogen is too reactive to belong to any group on the periodic table at all
distractors.explanation: Hydrogen does belong in Group 1 by electron configuration; its separate placement is about behavioural differences.

toLevel3.question: Which key group name matches the description: 'reactive non-metals that form salts when they react with metals'?
toLevel3.correctExplanation: The word 'halogen' means 'salt-former', reflecting their ability to react with metals to produce salts.

distractors.explanation: Noble gases are unreactive and do not form salts with metals.
Alkali metals are metals, not non-metals, and they react with halogens to form salts.
Alkaline earth metals are metals that react with halogens, but they are not the salt-formers being described.

toLevel3.question: Alkaline earth metals in Group 2 have 2 valence electrons.
toLevel3.correctExplanation: All Group 2 elements have 2 electrons in their outer shell.

distractors.explanation: Students may confuse group number with period number, but Group 2 elements do have 2 valence electrons.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the sentence about the relationship between groups and properties.
toLevel3.sentence: Elements in the same group have similar chemical properties because they share the same number of {{blank:1}} electrons.

1.correctExplanation: Valence electrons determine chemical behaviour, and elements in the same group have the same number of them.

distractors.explanation: Total electron count varies down a group; it is valence electrons that stay the same.
Inner shell electron counts vary down a group; valence electrons are what remain constant.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the sentence about the meaning of group names.
toLevel3.sentence: The word 'halogen' means {{blank:1}}, reflecting the fact that these elements react with metals to produce {{blank:2}}.

1.correctExplanation: The Greek roots 'halo' (salt) and 'gen' (to produce) give halogens the meaning 'salt-formers'.

distractors.explanation: Not all halogens are gases; bromine is a liquid and iodine is a solid at room temperature.
While some halogens are used in lighting, the name means salt-former.

2.correctExplanation: When halogens react with metals, they form ionic compounds known as salts (e.g., sodium chloride).

distractors.explanation: While halogens can form acids, their name refers to salt formation with metals.
The products of halogen-metal reactions are solid salts, not gases.

toLevel3.prompt: Complete the sentence about group names and their locations.
toLevel3.sentence: On the far right of the periodic table, Group {{blank:1}} contains the {{blank:2}}, which are known for their chemical stability.

1.correctExplanation: Group 18 is the rightmost group on the periodic table.

distractors.explanation: Group 1 is on the far left, not the far right.
Group 17 is second from the right; Group 18 is the rightmost.

2.correctExplanation: Noble gases in Group 18 have full outer shells, making them very stable.

distractors.explanation: Halogens are in Group 17, not Group 18.
Alkali metals are in Group 1 on the far left.

toLevel4.question: A student finds an element with the electron configuration 2, 8, 8, 1. Which key group does this element belong to?
toLevel4.correctExplanation: 1 valence electron places this element in Group 1, the alkali metals. This is potassium.

distractors.explanation: Noble gases have full outer shells (8 valence electrons), not 1.
Halogens have 7 valence electrons, not 1.
Alkaline earth metals have 2 valence electrons, not 1.

toLevel4.question: An element is a gas at room temperature, is unreactive, and has a full outer electron shell. Identify which group it belongs to.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Unreactive gases with full outer shells are noble gases in Group 18.

distractors.explanation: Halogens are reactive non-metals, not unreactive.
Alkali metals are highly reactive solids, not unreactive gases.
Alkaline earth metals are reactive solids, not unreactive gases.

toLevel4.question: An unknown element reacts vigorously with water, is a soft metal, and has 1 valence electron. Name the group it belongs to and give an example element.
toLevel4.correct: Alkali metals; examples include sodium and potassium
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Soft metals with 1 valence electron that react with water are alkali metals.

distractors.answer: Alkaline earth metals; examples include magnesium and calcium
distractors.explanation: Alkaline earth metals have 2 valence electrons and are less vigorously reactive with water.

distractors.answer: Halogens; examples include chlorine and bromine
distractors.explanation: Halogens are non-metals with 7 valence electrons.

distractors.answer: Transition metals; examples include iron and copper
distractors.explanation: Transition metals are generally hard, not soft, and most do not react vigorously with water.

toLevel4.question: Use the electron configuration 2, 8, 7 to determine which key group this element belongs to.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: 7 valence electrons places this element in Group 17, the halogens. This is chlorine.

distractors.explanation: Noble gases have 8 valence electrons (or 2 for helium), not 7.
Alkali metals have 1 valence electron, not 7.
Alkaline earth metals have 2 valence electrons, not 7.

toLevel4.question: Predict the properties of an element in Group 2, Period 4. Which key group does it belong to and what type of reactions would you expect?
toLevel4.correct: Alkaline earth metal; it would react with water and form ionic compounds with non-metals
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Group 2 elements are alkaline earth metals that react with water and form 2+ ions in ionic bonding.

distractors.answer: Halogen; it would gain electrons to form negative ions easily
distractors.explanation: Halogens are in Group 17 and gain electrons; Group 2 elements lose electrons.

distractors.answer: Noble gas; it would be unreactive and exist as individual atoms
distractors.explanation: Noble gases are in Group 18; Group 2 elements are reactive metals.

distractors.answer: Alkali metal; it would explode on contact with water instantly
distractors.explanation: Group 2 metals react with water less vigorously than Group 1 alkali metals.

toLevel4.question: A reactive non-metal needs to gain 1 electron to achieve a stable configuration. It forms salts with metals. Identify the group and provide an example.
toLevel4.correct: Halogens (Group 17); examples include fluorine and bromine
toLevel4.correctExplanation: Needing 1 electron to fill the outer shell and forming salts identifies this as a halogen.

distractors.answer: Noble gases (Group 18); examples include neon and argon
distractors.explanation: Noble gases already have full shells and do not need to gain electrons.

distractors.answer: Alkali metals (Group 1); examples include lithium and sodium
distractors.explanation: Alkali metals lose electrons; they do not gain them.

distractors.answer: Alkaline earth metals (Group 2); examples include beryllium and barium
distractors.explanation: Alkaline earth metals lose 2 electrons; they do not gain electrons.

toLevel4.question: Determine which key group an element belongs to if it has the electron configuration 2, 8, 8 and is completely unreactive.
toLevel4.correctExplanation: A full outer shell of 8 electrons and complete unreactivity identifies this as argon, a noble gas.

distractors.explanation: Halogens have 7 valence electrons and are very reactive.
Alkaline earth metals have 2 valence electrons and are reactive.
Alkali metals have 1 valence electron and are highly reactive.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the sentence identifying group membership from properties.
toLevel4.sentence: An element that is a soft, shiny metal with {{blank:1}} valence electron(s) and reacts vigorously with water belongs to the {{blank:2}}.

distractors.explanation: 7 valence electrons belong to halogens, not alkali metals.
2 valence electrons belong to alkaline earth metals, not alkali metals.

2.correctExplanation: The described properties match the alkali metals in Group 1.

distractors.explanation: Halogens are non-metals, not soft shiny metals.
Noble gases are unreactive; they do not react with water.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the sentence about group identification.
toLevel4.sentence: Elements with a {{blank:1}} outer electron shell are noble gases and are found in Group {{blank:2}}.

1.correctExplanation: Noble gases have completely filled outer shells, which accounts for their stability.

distractors.explanation: Half-full shells are not characteristic of noble gases; they have completely full shells.
Noble gases do not have empty outer shells; their stability comes from full shells.

2.correctExplanation: Noble gases are located in Group 18, the rightmost group.

distractors.explanation: Group 1 contains the alkali metals.
While older naming used Group 8, the modern IUPAC group number for noble gases is 18.

toLevel4.prompt: Complete the sentence applying group knowledge.
toLevel4.sentence: Calcium is in Group 2, making it an {{blank:1}}. It has {{blank:2}} valence electrons and tends to lose them in reactions.

1.correctExplanation: Group 2 elements are called alkaline earth metals.

distractors.explanation: Alkali metals are in Group 1; calcium is in Group 2.
Halogens are non-metals in Group 17; calcium is a metal in Group 2.

2.correctExplanation: All Group 2 elements have 2 valence electrons.

distractors.explanation: 1 valence electron is characteristic of Group 1, not Group 2.
8 valence electrons describes a noble gas, not an alkaline earth metal.

toLevel5.question: Compare the alkali metals (Group 1) and alkaline earth metals (Group 2). Why are alkali metals generally more reactive than alkaline earth metals in the same period?
toLevel5.correct: Alkali metals have only 1 electron to lose, while alkaline earth metals must lose 2, requiring more energy
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Losing 1 electron is energetically easier than losing 2, making alkali metals more reactive.

distractors.answer: Alkali metals have more protons creating stronger reactions with non-metals
distractors.explanation: Alkali metals actually have fewer protons than their Period-matched alkaline earth metals.

distractors.answer: Alkaline earth metals have full outer shells making them stable like noble gases
distractors.explanation: Alkaline earth metals have 2 outer electrons, not full shells.

distractors.answer: Alkali metals are lighter so they react faster in water due to their lower density
distractors.explanation: While some alkali metals are lighter, reactivity is determined by electron loss energy, not mass.

toLevel5.question: Analyse why noble gases were not discovered until the late 1800s, long after many other elements were known.
toLevel5.correct: Their unreactivity meant they did not form compounds, making them difficult to detect through chemical methods
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Chemical analysis of the time relied on reactions. Since noble gases rarely react, they went undetected.

distractors.answer: Noble gases are extremely rare on Earth and barely exist in nature at all
distractors.explanation: Argon makes up about 1% of the atmosphere; it is not rare, just chemically invisible.

distractors.answer: Scientists intentionally ignored noble gases because they were considered unimportant
distractors.explanation: Scientists were unaware of their existence, not ignoring them.

distractors.answer: Noble gases are invisible and cannot be collected in any container
distractors.explanation: Many gases are invisible; noble gases can be collected and were eventually isolated.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate why elements within the same group show predictable trends in their physical properties (such as melting point and density) despite having the same chemical behaviour.
toLevel5.correct: Physical properties depend on atomic size and mass which change down the group, while chemical behaviour depends on identical valence electron counts
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Same valence electrons ensure similar chemistry, but increasing size and mass alter physical properties systematically.

distractors.answer: Physical properties and chemical behaviour are completely independent and unrelated
distractors.explanation: Both are connected to electron structure, but they depend on different aspects of it.

distractors.answer: Elements in the same group have identical physical and chemical properties overall
distractors.explanation: Physical properties like melting point and density vary significantly down a group.

distractors.answer: Physical property trends are random and cannot be predicted from group membership
distractors.explanation: Physical properties follow predictable trends based on position within the group.

toLevel5.question: A student groups helium with the alkaline earth metals because it has 2 electrons. Evaluate this classification.
toLevel5.correct: Helium belongs with the noble gases because its outer shell (shell 1) is full with 2 electrons, making it stable and unreactive
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The first shell holds a maximum of 2 electrons, so helium has a full outer shell like other noble gases.

distractors.answer: The student is correct because 2 electrons means it should be in Group 2
distractors.explanation: Having 2 total electrons does not mean Group 2; helium's first shell is full, making it a noble gas.

distractors.answer: Helium does not fit in any group because it is too simple an atom to classify
distractors.explanation: Helium is classified in Group 18 with the noble gases based on its full outer shell.

distractors.answer: Helium should be in Group 1 because it has fewer electrons than any alkaline earth metal
distractors.explanation: Group placement depends on electron arrangement, not total count; helium's full shell places it with noble gases.

toLevel5.question: Analyse why the halogens become less reactive down the group while alkali metals become more reactive down their group, even though both trends are caused by increasing atomic radius.
toLevel5.correct: Halogens need to attract electrons (harder with larger radius) while alkali metals need to release electrons (easier with larger radius)
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The same physical change (bigger atoms) has opposite effects on gaining vs losing electrons.

distractors.answer: The two groups actually follow the same trend but scientists measure reactivity differently for each
distractors.explanation: The trends are genuinely opposite, not measurement artefacts.

distractors.answer: Halogens and alkali metals have different numbers of valence electrons so the trends cannot be compared
distractors.explanation: The trends can be compared; the difference is in the type of reaction (gaining vs losing electrons).

distractors.answer: Alkali metals are affected by atomic radius but halogens are not affected by it
distractors.explanation: Both groups are affected by atomic radius; the effect simply has opposite consequences for each.

toLevel5.question: Consider an element that could be classified as either a halogen or a metalloid based on different properties. What determines its group classification on the modern periodic table?
toLevel5.correct: Its number of valence electrons and therefore its position by atomic number
toLevel5.correctExplanation: The periodic table classifies by atomic number and electron configuration, not by individual physical properties.

distractors.answer: Its physical appearance determines the primary group classification
distractors.explanation: Appearance can vary; electron configuration is the definitive classifier.

distractors.answer: Scientists vote on where to place ambiguous elements each decade
distractors.explanation: Placement is determined by atomic number and electron structure, not by vote.

distractors.answer: Elements can belong to two groups simultaneously if they share properties
distractors.explanation: Each element occupies exactly one position based on its atomic number.

toLevel5.question: Predict the group name and typical behaviour of an element with 53 protons, knowing that it has 7 valence electrons.
toLevel5.correct: It is a halogen that will gain 1 electron to form a 1âˆ’ ion
toLevel5.correctExplanation: 7 valence electrons places it in Group 17 (halogens). This is iodine, which gains 1 electron to achieve a full outer shell.

distractors.answer: It is a noble gas that is completely unreactive at room temperature
distractors.explanation: Noble gases have 8 valence electrons; 7 valence electrons identifies a halogen.

distractors.answer: It is an alkali metal that will lose 7 electrons to form a 7+ ion
distractors.explanation: Losing 7 electrons is energetically impractical; it gains 1 electron instead.

distractors.answer: It is a transition metal with variable valence and multiple oxidation states
distractors.explanation: 7 valence electrons in the outermost shell identifies a main group element (halogen), not a transition metal.

toLevel5.question: Evaluate why the periodic table groups elements by atomic number rather than by physical properties such as state at room temperature.
toLevel5.correct: Atomic number reveals electron configuration, which predicts chemical behaviour more reliably than physical state
toLevel5.correctExplanation: Electron configuration determines chemical properties. Physical state can vary within a group and does not reliably predict chemistry.

distractors.answer: Physical properties would create a more useful table but are too hard to measure accurately
distractors.explanation: Physical properties are easily measured but do not group elements by chemical similarity as effectively.

distractors.answer: Grouping by physical state would produce the same arrangement as grouping by atomic number
distractors.explanation: Grouping by state would scatter related elements; mercury (liquid metal) would not group with other metals.

distractors.answer: The periodic table was designed before physical properties were understood by scientists
distractors.explanation: Physical properties were well understood; atomic number was chosen because it produces more meaningful chemical groupings.

toLevel5.prompt: Complete the sentence analysing group characteristics.
toLevel5.sentence: The key difference between alkali metals and alkaline earth metals is that alkali metals have {{blank:1}} valence electron(s) while alkaline earth metals have {{blank:2}}, making alkali metals generally more reactive.

1.correctExplanation: Alkali metals in Group 1 have 1 valence electron.

distractors.explanation: 2 valence electrons belongs to Group 2 alkaline earth metals.
7 valence electrons belongs to Group 17 halogens.

2.correctExplanation: Alkaline earth metals in Group 2 have 2 valence electrons.

distractors.explanation: 1 valence electron belongs to Group 1 alkali metals.
8 valence electrons (full shell) belongs to Group 18 noble gases.

toLevel5.prompt: Complete the sentence evaluating group properties.
toLevel5.sentence: Noble gases are unique among the key groups because they have {{blank:1}} outer shells, meaning they do not need to {{blank:2}} electrons to achieve stability.

1.correctExplanation: Noble gases have completely filled outer electron shells.

distractors.explanation: Noble gases have full outer shells, not empty ones.
Half-filled shells are not characteristic of noble gases; theirs are completely full.

2.correctExplanation: With full outer shells, noble gases have no need to gain or lose electrons.

distractors.explanation: Electrons are neither created nor destroyed in chemical reactions.
Absorbing and emitting relates to energy, not the electron transfer in chemical bonding.
